thesis: Uber is down 30% from 52-week highs and 14% YTD at ~$70-73, creating a deep value contrarian opportunity. Despite the Q4 EPS miss ($0.71 vs $0.7788), revenue grew 20% YoY to $14.37B. The company is aggressively investing in robotaxi infrastructure — $100M in charging hubs today, $500M Waabi partnership, 20+ AV partnerships globally. Consensus PT ~$105, implying 50% upside from current levels. Uber's asset-light autonomy model — providing the demand network while partners supply the vehicles — is potentially the winning strategy for robotaxis. New robotaxi-bull CFO signals deeper commitment. The stock trades at just 15x trailing earnings despite 20% growth, which is deeply undervalued for a tech platform at this scale (9.4M drivers, 200M users). This provides critical non-semiconductor, non-AI-infrastructure diversification.
entry_trigger: UBER at ~$70-73 after 30% drawdown from highs. Buy $75 worth if stock holds above $68 for 2 sessions. The Q1 guidance of $52-53.5B gross bookings (17-21% growth) provides a floor. Robotaxi charging hub investment today is a positive catalyst. Do NOT buy if stock breaks below $65.
exit_trigger: Target $90-100 (25-40% upside) over 3-4 months as robotaxi narrative gains traction and growth re-rates the multiple. Take partial profits at $85. Stop loss at $60.

thesis: Analog Devices reported a blowout Q1 FY2026: Revenue $3.16B (+30% YoY), beating $3.12B estimate. Adjusted EPS $2.46 beat $2.31 consensus. Communications revenue grew 63%, Industrial revenue +38%, with record data center orders. Q2 guidance: EPS $2.88 (vs $2.31 consensus — massive beat). Data center business grew ~50% in FY2025 and accelerated further. ADI's analog/mixed-signal power and optical portfolios are critical for AI data center evolution. Stock hit 52-week high at ~$346. This is a less crowded way to play the AI data center infrastructure theme vs NVDA/AMD. Industrial cyclical recovery provides additional tailwind. Adjusted gross margin improved 240 bps to 71.2% and operating margin 500 bps to 45.5%. Dividend raised 11%.
entry_trigger: ADI at $346 is at 52-week highs after earnings surge. Do NOT chase today. Wait for any post-earnings consolidation to $330-340 range. If broader market volatility from NVDA earnings (Feb 25) or other events pulls ADI back, that's the entry. Buy $75 worth on any 3-5% pullback. UBS has $400 PT.
exit_trigger: Target $380-400 (10-15% upside) over 3-4 months as data center and industrial cycles continue strengthening. Take partial profits at $375. Stop loss at $310.

thesis: Datadog (DDOG) is an AI-native observability platform that benefits from both the data center buildout AND the complexity of managing AI workloads. DA Davidson maintains Buy with $225 PT today. As companies deploy more AI infrastructure, they need monitoring/observability tools — DDOG is the leader in this space. Unlike pure SaaS companies getting disrupted by AI (ORCL, INTU down 3-5% today), DDOG's product becomes MORE necessary as AI complexity increases. The company has been growing revenue 25%+ and expanding its platform with AI-specific monitoring features. The software sector selloff has likely pulled DDOG down unfairly — AI observability is different from traditional SaaS. This provides cloud software diversification for our portfolio that is AI-enabling rather than AI-disrupted.
entry_trigger: DDOG with DA Davidson Buy/$225 PT. If current price is 20%+ below PT, entry is attractive. Buy $75 worth on any further software sector pullback. Look for stabilization after the Anthropic/AI software panic subsides. Do NOT chase above $180.
exit_trigger: Target $200-225 over 3-4 months based on DA Davidson PT. Take partial profits at $195. Stop loss at 20% below entry.

thesis: Cameco (CCJ) is a pure-play nuclear/uranium company that benefits directly from the AI data center power demand narrative. RBC Capital today raised its price target and maintains Outperform. Nuclear power is the most reliable clean baseload power source for data centers — Amazon-backed nuclear companies just got US approval for reactor fuel. Microsoft, Google, and Amazon have all signed nuclear power agreements. The global uranium supply deficit is structural with limited new mine capacity. CCJ provides energy infrastructure diversification away from both semiconductors and traditional tech, while being positively correlated with the AI buildout theme. With gold pulling back sharply (down 3% today) and our GLD position under pressure, nuclear/uranium offers a better non-tech inflation/infrastructure hedge than precious metals in the current environment.
entry_trigger: Research current CCJ price levels. If trading below $70 with RBC Outperform rating, buy $75 worth. Nuclear power demand for AI data centers is a secular multi-year theme. Enter on any broad market pullback this week. Do NOT chase above recent highs.
exit_trigger: Target 15-20% upside over 3-6 months as nuclear power demand for AI data centers accelerates. Take partial profits at 15% gain. Stop loss at 15% below entry.

thesis: Walmart reports Q4 FY2026 earnings on Feb 19 before open. The company became the first traditional retailer to hit $1T market cap in Feb 2026, up ~20% YTD. E-commerce grew 27% globally, advertising up 53%, membership income up 17%. Revenue forecast $190.4B. AI transformation with "Wally" generative AI and logistics optimization is driving margin expansion. WMT provides perfect defensive diversification for our semiconductor-heavy portfolio — consumer staples hold up in volatile markets. General Mills just warned about weak consumer sentiment, but WMT's value proposition typically strengthens in uncertain times. Previous quarter beat EPS by 3.33% and revenue by 1.16%. The stock moved to NASDAQ from NYSE in Dec 2025, signaling tech-company identity. Risk: At $1T valuation, expectations are very high. Any miss could trigger significant downside.
entry_trigger: WMT reports Feb 19 before open. Do NOT buy pre-earnings given $1T valuation risk. If WMT beats and guides up, buy $75 worth on any post-earnings pullback to consolidation. If it misses or guides cautiously due to consumer weakness (General Mills warned about this), avoid entirely. Only enter post-earnings with confirmed beat.
exit_trigger: Target 10-12% upside over 3-4 months as defensive rotation continues and e-commerce/advertising growth compounds. Take partial profits at 8% gain. Stop loss at 10% below entry.

thesis: PANW reported Q2 FY2026: Revenue $2.6B (+15% YoY), non-GAAP EPS $1.03 (beat $0.93-0.95 guidance), NGS ARR grew 33% to $6.33B, RPO $16B. However, Q3 guidance disappointed: non-GAAP EPS $0.78-$0.80 vs $0.92 consensus, due to CyberArk ($25B) and Chronosphere ($3B+) acquisition integration costs. Stock fell ~7-8% to ~$163-167 post-earnings. Full-year guidance: revenue $11.28-11.31B (22-23% growth), non-GAAP EPS $3.65-3.70. The platformization thesis is intact — NGS ARR acceleration to 50%+ guided for Q3. But near-term margin dilution from massive M&A creates a "growing pains" period. CrowdStrike may benefit short-term as PANW integrates. The pullback creates a potential entry for patient investors, but the guidance miss means waiting for stabilization.
entry_trigger: PANW at ~$163-167 post-earnings pullback. Wait for stabilization at $155-165 over 2-3 sessions. If it holds above $155, buy $75 worth. The Q3 EPS guide miss will keep pressure short-term but NGS ARR growth of 33% and full-year revenue guide of 22-23% growth are strong. Do NOT chase below $150 as that signals deeper concerns.
exit_trigger: Target $190-210 over 3-4 months as CyberArk integration starts showing revenue synergies. Take partial profits at $185. Stop loss at $140.

thesis: Snowflake surged ~6.4% today to $184 on what appears to be institutional accumulation (CNBC reported Amy Raskin bought more SNOW). The stock is a direct AI data infrastructure beneficiary — as companies deploy AI models, they need data platforms to organize, govern, and serve data for AI workloads. SNOW is transitioning from a data warehouse to an AI-native data platform with Cortex AI features. The AI disruption narrative is creating a bifurcation in software: companies whose products are replaced by AI (PINS -20% today) vs companies whose products are essential FOR AI (SNOW benefits). Data infrastructure is essential infrastructure for the AI buildout. SNOW reports earnings Feb 26 (day after NVDA), which could be a positive catalyst if data consumption metrics show AI-driven acceleration. The stock is down significantly from 52-week highs, creating an asymmetric entry. SNOW provides true software/data diversification for our semiconductor-heavy portfolio.
entry_trigger: SNOW at ~$184 today, up 6.4%. Wait for any pullback to $170-180 range. If broader market weakness from Supreme Court ruling (Feb 20) pulls SNOW back to $170-175, buy $75 worth. Alternatively, if NVDA earnings on Feb 25 are strong and SNOW gaps up on AI sentiment before its own earnings Feb 26, consider a smaller $50 pre-earnings position if below $185. Do NOT chase above $195.
exit_trigger: Target $220-240 (20-30% upside from $180 entry) over 3-4 months as AI data infrastructure demand accelerates. Take partial profits at $210. Stop loss at $150 (below recent support).

thesis: NextEra Energy just raised its quarterly dividend to $0.6232 from $0.57 (a 9.3% increase) and is trading at all-time highs. The rotation out of tech into utilities and energy infrastructure is a clear market theme — 'old economy' sectors are outperforming as investors seek AI-adjacent plays without direct AI valuation risk. NEE benefits from: 1) Data center power demand (nuclear/renewables), 2) Amazon-backed nuclear company just got US approval for reactor fuel, 3) Rate cut expectations boost utility valuations, 4) Dividend growth provides income floor, 5) The infrastructure rotation is expected to persist as portfolio managers trim tech. NEE provides true non-tech diversification for our semiconductor-heavy portfolio.
entry_trigger: NEE at all-time highs — do NOT chase. Wait for any 3-5% pullback from current levels. If Supreme Court tariff ruling on Feb 20 creates broad market volatility, NEE could pull back providing an entry. Buy $75 worth on any 3-5% dip from current highs. The dividend increase provides a valuation floor.
exit_trigger: Target 10-15% upside over 3-4 months as utility sector rotation continues. Take partial profits at 10% gain. Stop loss at 12% below entry.

thesis: Coinbase is trading near 52-week lows around $140-141, down 37% YTD despite strong operational metrics: trading volume and market share doubled in 2025, 12 products now generate $100M+ annualized revenue, Coinbase One subscriptions reached 1M. Q4 revenue missed ($1.78B vs $1.85B) and the stock posted a $667M net loss due to crypto mark-to-market, but adjusted EPS of $0.66 beat $0.64. Bitcoin surged 5% today to $69,000 — if crypto market recovers, COIN has massive operating leverage. The $2B expanded buyback signals management confidence. The stock is at extreme pessimism with a 52-week range of $139-$445. Pro-crypto regulatory environment under current administration. This is a deep value contrarian play that provides non-AI diversification.
entry_trigger: COIN at ~$140-142, right near 52-week low of $139.36. If it holds above $135 for 2 sessions and Bitcoin stabilizes above $65,000, buy $75 worth. The extreme pessimism and proximity to 52-week low creates asymmetric upside. Do NOT buy if Bitcoin drops below $60,000 or COIN breaks below $130.
exit_trigger: Target $180-200 (28-43% upside) over 3-4 months as crypto market recovers. Take partial profits at $170. Stop loss at $125 (below 52-week low support).

thesis: Corsair Gaming (CRSR) surged 55% today after a Q4 double beat: EPS $0.43 vs $0.27 estimate, revenue $436.9M vs $421M estimate. The company announced a $50M buyback. This is a consumer electronics/gaming play that provides pure diversification away from our AI/semiconductor names. The 55% surge on earnings indicates extremely strong positive surprise factor. However, FY2026 revenue guidance of $1.33-1.47B came in below $1.59B estimate, which adds uncertainty. At the surged price, wait for consolidation before entering. The gaming peripherals market is cyclical but Corsair's double beat suggests the cycle is turning.
entry_trigger: CRSR surged ~55% today. Do NOT chase. Wait 3-5 sessions for post-earnings consolidation. The stock will likely give back some of the surge given the below-consensus FY2026 guidance. If CRSR pulls back 15-20% from surge highs and stabilizes, buy $50 worth. Look for entry in the pullback consolidation zone.
exit_trigger: Target 20% upside from consolidation entry over 3-4 months as gaming cycle improves. Take partial profits at 15% gain. Stop loss at 25% below entry.

FY2026 revenue guidance of $15.6-16.0B vs $15.691B consensus. This is a genuine non-tech, non-AI diversifier for our heavily semiconductor-weighted portfolio. Travel demand remains robust with B2B bookings growing 26% in Q3 (17th consecutive quarter of double-digit growth). EXPE is trading at ~$241 pre-earnings, down 22% from its Jan 9 all-time high of $303.80. Analyst average target is $280.92 (23.6% upside). The earnings beat combined with the pullback from ATH creates attractive entry on consolidation.

FY2026 guidance of $5.65-5.7B massively beat $5.46B consensus. Software sector got a relief bounce today with Salesforce and Oracle up 3-4%. CPI came in tame which supports growth stocks. The software rotation trade may be turning — if TWLO can stabilize above $105-110, the asymmetric upside is compelling.

thesis: Roku crushed Q4 2025 earnings: EPS $0.53 vs $0.27 consensus (93% beat), revenue $1.395B beat $1.35B estimate (+16% YoY). First full-year profit in company history. Platform revenue grew 18% to $4.15B. Streaming hours up 15% to 145.6B. The Roku Channel is now #2 in free ad-supported streaming by usage behind only YouTube. For 2026, Roku guided total revenue to $5.5B (+16%) with adjusted EBITDA nearly quintupling to $635M. Premium subscription bundles are a new growth engine. Approaching 100M streaming households. This is a profitable, growing, non-AI-pure-play that provides portfolio diversification away from our semiconductor-heavy holdings. At current prices, the valuation becomes very reasonable with the profitability inflection.
entry_trigger: ROKU surged ~13% after hours on massive earnings beat. Do NOT chase the gap-up. Wait 2-3 sessions for post-earnings consolidation. If ROKU pulls back to $115-125 from initial reaction, buy $75 worth. If it holds above the earnings-day close for 3 sessions, consider a smaller $50 entry at market.
exit_trigger: Target $145-160 (20-35% upside from $120 entry) over 3-4 months as profitability thesis plays out. Take partial profits at $140. Stop loss at $95 (below pre-earnings level).

thesis: CROX thesis confirmed: Goldman Sachs maintains Sell with raised PT to $81 — a contrarian signal given the 13%+ earnings surge and strong guidance. Multiple analysts raising forecasts post-Q4. Wait for post-earnings consolidation as the Goldman Sell rating may weigh on sentiment near-term.

Multiple top analysts (BofA, JPM, Wells Fargo, Morgan Stanley) maintained Buy/Overweight ratings. BofA notes 'revenue growth accelerating to 8.5% in 2026' and finds 'valuation attractive at ~18.5x forward P/E.' The selloff appears overblown. AI infrastructure orders of $2.1B with full-year projection of $5B+ are strong. Wait for stabilization in the $75-80 range.

thesis: AMAT CONFIRMED and BIS RESOLVED: AMAT surged ~10-13% on Feb 13 on strong earnings beat (EPS $2.38 vs $2.20, guidance $7.15-8.15B vs $7.01B est). AMAT settled BIS China export allegations for $252.5M — DOJ and SEC closed their investigations without action. This removes a major legal overhang. Multiple analyst upgrades: Citigroup $420, Goldman $390, Stifel $450, TD Cowen $450, Wells Fargo $435 (Overweight), BofA $420 (Buy). CEO projects 20%+ semiconductor growth in 2026. The BIS settlement is a near-term cash hit but long-term positive — removes uncertainty and allows focus on execution. Wait for post-surge consolidation.
entry_trigger: AMAT surged to ~$370+ today. Do NOT chase at current levels. Wait for post-earnings consolidation to $350-365 over 1-2 weeks. If it pulls back to $350-360 and stabilizes, buy $100 worth. Wells Fargo notes semi systems revenue expected to grow >20% YoY. Do NOT chase above $380.
exit_trigger: Target $420-450 (15-22% upside from $370) over 3-4 months based on upgraded analyst PTs. Take partial profits at $400. Stop loss at $330.

thesis: ETN trading at ~$389 on Feb 11, near 52-week high of $399.56. At ~37x earnings, valuation is demanding. AI infrastructure tailwind is real but largely priced in at current levels. CFO departing April 2026 adds uncertainty.

If stock pulls back 5% to $370 area, buy $75 worth. The data center power demand narrative provides a fundamental floor around $340-350.

Despite revenue beat and $2B buyback, the market is punishing the EPS miss and margin guidance. SHOP is now trading 28% below its 52-week high of $182. Software sector headwinds persist. The post-earnings reversal is bearish short-term — wait for full stabilization.
entry_trigger: SHOP closed at $123.61 after massive intraday reversal from $145 to $122. Wait 3-5 sessions for post-earnings dust to settle. If SHOP stabilizes at $118-125 and holds above $112 (January low), buy $75 worth. The revenue beat and $2B buyback provide a floor. Do NOT buy if it breaks below $110.

thesis: ORCL remains under software sector pressure. Software stocks have been hammered by AI disruption fears — down 16.8% on average over the past month. ORCL is caught in this downdraft. However, the broader market narrative around software companies may be starting to shift as companies like Twilio (beat and guided up with 2026 revenue $5.65-5.7B vs $5.46B est) demonstrate that AI is becoming an enabler rather than just a disruptor. ORCL March 9 earnings remains a binary event. With $130B debt and dilution concerns, maintain cautious stance but monitor for software sector stabilization.
entry_trigger: Wait for software selloff to stabilize. Only consider if ORCL pulls back to $130-135 range with clear signs of sector rotation ending. The March 9 earnings could be a catalyst but software sentiment may remain negative into that event.

Meta expanding Nvidia AI chip deal is a bullish signal. Estimated EPS $1.52. NVDA partnered with Meta for next-gen chips. thesis: Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) reported record Q4 revenue of $751.2M (beat estimates, +20.8% YoY) and full-year revenue of $2.8B (+26.4%). CEO raised the enterprise data growth floor to 50% for 2026 (up from 30-40%). Book-to-bill ratio is well above 1 with backlog extending into Q2-Q3 2026. The company increased its dividend 28% to $2/share, signaling confidence. MPWR is a high-quality AI power management play with diversification across auto (43% growth), data center, and communications. At ~$1,207 after earnings, with Oppenheimer targeting $1,300 and Stifel at $1,300, there's ~8% near-term upside from multiple analyst upgrades. The power management layer of AI infrastructure is a less crowded, high-margin way to play the AI capex theme.

thesis: CAT continues to be overvalued after surging 6-7% on Feb 6 and hitting an all-time intraday high above $720. The stock is now up 25% YTD. While the AI data center power story is real (record backlog), the stock is pricing in perfection at ~32x earnings. Risk/reward is poor at these levels. Avoid buying.
